title: Query Adaptive Few-Shot Object Detection with Heterogeneous Graph Convolutional Networks

sections.the baseline fsod model:
As shown in Fig.Â 2, we mainly follow Fan et al.â€™s work [ref]3 to build our baseline FSOD model, which adopts a siamese Faster R-CNN (with ResNet [ref]12) with two branches. In one branch, a query image Iqsubscriptğ¼ğ‘I_{q} is fed into the feature extraction network to extract its feature râ€‹(Iq)ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ¼ğ‘r(I_{q}) (output of râ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹4ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ 4res4 block) for the detection head. Similarly, the other branch extracts the feature râ€‹(Is)ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ¼ğ‘ r(I_{s}) given an input support image Issubscriptğ¼ğ‘ I_{s}. Then the Attention-RPN [ref]3 is used to produce Nğ‘N (N=100ğ‘100N=100 by default following [ref]3) class-specific proposals Pc={{pic}i=1N,picâˆˆU}subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ˆP_{c}=\{\{p_{i}^{c}\}_{i=1}^{N},p_{i}^{c}\in U\} for the novel class câˆˆCnâ€‹oâ€‹vâ€‹eâ€‹lğ‘subscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘£ğ‘’ğ‘™c\in C_{novel}. After that, we use the râ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹5ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ 5res5 block and RoIPooling [ref]6 to extract the feature f(pic)âˆˆâ„HÃ—WÃ—C(H=W=7,C=2048)f(p_{i}^{c})\in\mathbb{R}^{H\times W\times C}(H=W=7,C=2048) for proposal picsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘p_{i}^{c} from the query image feature râ€‹(Iq)ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ¼ğ‘r(I_{q}).
We apply the same layers to râ€‹(Is)ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ¼ğ‘ r(I_{s}), and take the average feature of all support images belonging to the novel class cğ‘c as the class prototype fâ€‹(c)ğ‘“ğ‘f(c). After that, a multi-relation network [ref]3 is used to calculate similarity score between the proposal feature and the class prototype, and then produce the final detection results for class cğ‘c following . The above process will be applied to each novel class independently. The reason we use [ref]3 as our baseline model is as follows. Firstly, the whole framework is simple and elegant, and is a natural extension of the original Faster R-CNN to the few-shot setting. Secondly, as shown in the Section 6.3, it has achieved SOTA accuracy in major FSOD benchmarks. Although [ref]3 has been demonstrated to be a promising FSOD model, there are three potential limits as discussed in the Section 1, and the primary cause is the separate classification of each proposal and class pair. To deal with this problem, we propose a novel FSOD model with heterogeneous GCNs in the following Section.
